title: Cruiseo sets out to help lines win first-timers
text:
Save 
A young entrepreneur is hoping to shake up the online cruise sales market with a new bookable website, cruiseo.com 
The company is the brainchild of James Werth, who has worked with travel technology business Digital Trip to develop an online matchmaking tool that recommends specific cruises to browsers. 
He claims the website, which is due to go live in the next couple of weeks, is one of the first to guide people to find their perfect cruise and enable them to book it online, rather than having to phone a call centre to make the booking, as is usually the case. 
Werth used personal funds to get the project off the ground, after working for the Royal Bank of Scotland graduate scheme while selling cruises for an American agency from home. 
He gained a place in London’s Accelerator Academy, which put Cruiseo in front of investors, enabling it to secure funding. 
Werth has pitched his idea to no fewer than 15 cruise lines including Royal Caribbean International and Azamara Club Cruises. 
“Cruise lines have been very interested in and excited by my proposition,” he said. “By their own admission, they are poor at attracting new-to-cruise. I’m seeking advice from lines who see this as an opportunity - we have some champions out there.” 
“We ask users about themselves and their travel preferences, get them to rate the features that are most important to them, and the algorithm throws back a shortlist of cruises most suitable for their needs,” he said. 
He hopes the tailor-made online format of the site will be particularly attractive to the new-to-cruise market. “Millennials don’t always understand the cruise concept, but other sites don’t talk to first-time cruisers. We will talk to them in a fun, non-corporate, start-up way. 
“They might be online during their lunch break or at 11pm, and they want answers immediately. Forcing people to make a phone call to book is so five years ago. We want to help millennials get the same answers online that they would get in a shop or via a call centre.” 
Werth added that ensuring the right customer was matched to the right cruise would help the site to grow by word of mouth, although he conceded that in the short term he was unable to rule out price matching to be competitive. 
“We don’t want to be a discount house, but if we have to price match to demonstrate a worthwhile concept, we will do it,” he admitted.
